docs.lead_paragraph: Carmen J. Pirollo expected his latest attempt to lose weight would take a while. At 5 feet 11 inches, he wanted to weigh 180 pounds, down from 260. A veteran dieter -- ''I've lost and gained a whole person in my lifetime'' -- he knew it would not be easy. But while Mr. Pirollo, a 55-year-old sixth-grade teacher in Haddon Heights, N.J., says he is healthy, he worries that his excess weight might take a toll on his health. And, of course, he wants to look good.

headline.main: Health and Money Issues Arise Over Who Pays for Weight Loss

docs.abstract: Medicare advisers will assess safety, efficacy and cost of increasingly popular method of weight loss--surgery--as first step in new policy that could lead to use of federal money to cover range of other obesity treatments; coverage by Medicare and other insurers may increase at time when evidence suggests that few obese people can lose significant amounts of weight in long term, and some obesity researchers question fundamental idea that losing weight improves health; reason for dearth of information on long-term effects of weight loss is that very few people keep weight off; currently, Medicare will pay for weight-loss surgery when patients suffer other problems associated with condition, like diabetes; new talks will discuss covering treatment for those who are simply obese; agency wants to determine if obesity treatments help people lose weight and improve their health; bariatric surgery costs $30,000 to $40,000; cost to Medicare for such coverage has not been determined; 61 million Americans are termed obese, including 9 million of Medicare age, 65 and older; photo (M)
docs.snippet: In November, Medicare's advisers will assess the safety, efficacy and cost of a popular method of weight loss: surgery.

docs.lead_paragraph: THE Library of Congress is giving $15 million to eight institutions to preserve a range of electronic material, including Web sites relating to the 2003 California gubernatorial recall election, digital maps, sound recordings and decades' worth of social science data. The grants, to be announced today, are part of a $100 million multiyear program, established by Congress and administered by the library, aimed at archiving resources that are increasingly born digital -- that is, as a Web site or an electronic database.

headline.main: Grants Will Preserve Paperless Bits of History

docs.abstract: Library of Congress gives $15 million to eight institutions to preserve electronic material of critical importance to cultural heritage and public policy; grants will total $100 million in coming years; photo (M)
docs.snippet: THE Library of Congress is giving $15 million to eight institutions to preserve a range of electronic material, including Web sites relating to the 2003 California gubernatorial recall election, digital maps, sound recordings and decades' worth of...

docs.lead_paragraph: Allan Houston could have gone the bravado route, proclaimed himself fit and guaranteed a full 82-game season for his much-scrutinized knees. For an antsy Knicks fan base, and a hopeful front office, those would have been welcome assurances. But Houston tried that approach once -- choosing aggression instead of prudence -- and the result was the most painful and disappointing season of his career. It is a course he would rather not travel again.
docs.abstract: New York Knicks player Allan Houston says he is optimistic but cautious about his physical fitness for upcoming NBA season; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Allan Houston called playing in the Nov. 3 season opener at Minnesota a realistic goal, but also said, "I don't think anything's a lock."

docs.lead_paragraph: A front-page article on Saturday about a ''faith based'' health savings account plan sponsored by OSF Health in Illinois misstated the number of plans available to federal workers there. The Mail Handlers Benefit Plan and the Government Employees Hospital Association will offer them for federal employees in all states; the OSF plan will not be the only one in Illinois.
docs.abstract: Correction of Sept 25 article on 'faith based' health savings account plan sponsored by OSF Health in Illinois regarding number of plans available
docs.snippet: A front-page article on Saturday about a ''faith based'' health savings account plan sponsored by OSF Health in Illinois misstated the number of plans available to federal workers there. The Mail Handlers Benefit Plan and the Government Employees...

docs.lead_paragraph: Schools and courts have closed for weeks on end. Roads, bridges, restaurants and hotels are in tatters, crops laid to waste and polling places for the coming election destroyed. Four back-to-back hurricanes have made normalcy ever more elusive in Florida, where intensive relief efforts cannot get traction helping people and whole industries cope. The logistical and financial hurdles are staggering: the Federal Emergency Management Agency has received more than 611,000 applications for assistance, and has been screening them at more than 60 recovery centers around the state. Though the agency delivered more than $330 million to individuals and businesses before Hurricane Jeanne blew through last weekend, thousands of applicants are still waiting.

headline.main: In Florida, Officials Are Hoping For One Final Storm Recovery

docs.abstract: Four back-to-back hurricanes in Florida have closed its schools and courts for weeks on end, left roads, bridges, restaurants and hotels in tatters, laid crops to waste and destroyed polling places for coming election; intensive relief efforts cannot get traction helping people and whole industries cope; logistical and financial hurdles are staggering; Federal Emergency Management Agency has received more than 611,000 applications for assistance and is processing them at more than 60 disaster recovery centers around states; charts; maps; photo (L)
docs.snippet: After four hurricanes, intensive reliefefforts cannot get traction helping people and whole industries cope.

byline.original: By ABBY GOODNOUGH; Carl Hulse contributed reporting from Washington for this article, Terry Aguayo from Miami and Dennis Blank from Kissimmee , Fla

docs.lead_paragraph: This year, as usual, the dominance of attack advertisements on television has made it hard to get a clear picture of where the candidates stand. But the same media revolution that brought us the 30-second commercial also brought us televised presidential debates -- and ever since the first of them 44 years ago, they have played a crucial role in shaping voters' opinions of the candidates. America has long been devoted to the clash between opposing advocates as the best way to evaluate information. In this era of media clutter, it is all the more important for voters to have this moment of simple clarity when the candidates appear before them stripped of advisers, sound bites and media spin.
docs.abstract: Al Gore Op-Ed article offers advice to Sen John Kerry on debating Pres Bush; contends that while Pres Bush's campaign has made 'lowered expectations' into a high art form, Bush is a skilled debater who uses format to his advantage; holds Bush's record as president offers Kerry a true opportunity because it amounts to 'a catastrophic failure' (L)
docs.snippet: My advice to John Kerry is simple: Attack the president on his catastrophic record, point for point.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Centene Corporation, a managed care company, agreed to buy two health plans for about $93 million to gain Medicaid patients in Kansas and Missouri. The acquisitions, from the closely held Swope Community Enterprises, will add as much as $260 million in revenue and 34 cents a share to earnings in 2005, Centene said. Michael Neidorff, Centene's chief executive, said in a statement that the purchase of the health plans in the Medicaid-mandated states would add 136,000 patients and two states to the company's 533,300 patients in Indiana, Ohio, Wisconsin, Texas and New Jersey. Stock in Centene, which is based in St. Louis, rose $4.81, to $43.51 a share.

headline.main: CENTENE TO ACQUIRE TWO HEALTH PLANS FOR $93 MILLION

docs.abstract: Centene Corp, managed care company, will buy two health plans for about $93 million from Swope Community Enterprises to gain Medicaid patients in Kansas and Missouri (S)
